title: Friday, 26th August, 2016
bodyHTML:

11:04 am

Mark Wall and George Buckley

PM

Serious piece of work

11:05 am
PM

Potential GDP growth slowed in the UK after the debt crisis and Brexit is
another structural shock. Monetary policy does not have the ability to
correct these impairments. A structural policy is required, for example, the
priority being given by new British PM, Theresa May, to the industrial
sector within economic policy. An industrial renaissance is the objective.
 We motivate the need for industrial strategy through the new informationbased
theory of economic growth. Over time, knowledge and knowhow is
created and embodied into products. The more specialized these products
and the broader the range produced, the more complex the economy.
Complexity is a medium- to long-term predictor of economic growth.
 The UK is not coming from a standing start. The UK has retained or
created industrial strengths in sectors from cars and industrial machinery
to aerospace and defense. The sizeable depreciation of sterling and
relatively low production costs give UK industry an advantage. These
cyclical benefits can be secured with a structural policy aimed at
maximizing R&D (knowledge) heavy, high-skill (knowhow) manufacturing.

PM

A modern industrial strategy is about creating the right environment for
new products and markets to emerge and jobs and income to grow. A
successful neo-industrial policy requires a holistic approach. We discuss
four areas likely to appear within an industrial strategy: infrastructure
(including digital), energy, skills and innovation. Policies here could
enhance complexity and the economy’s capacity to generate, share and
use information. A consistent policy approach with long-term
commitments could counterbalance Brexit-related uncertainty.
 The Chancellor, Philip Hammond, is expected to ease the UK’s austerity
policy by year-end. We argue the fiscal adjustment needs to be seen
through the lens of industrial strategy. Public sector funding costs are
extremely low and the Bank of England has re-started gilt-based QE. After
the referendum the government has a reason and opportunity to maximize
the benefits via an industrial policy.

PM

11:08 am
BE

Ah yes ........ Slightly odd statement.

PM

This has been a challenging trading period for our Leisure brands, albeit with a good performance from our pubs and concessions businesses. The Board has moved quickly to undertake a review of the operating strategy and we now have clarity on the issues facing our Leisure brands, particularly Frankie & Benny's. The brand remains relevant and popular and we are confident that improved performance will be achieved by being more customer-focussed and data-driven, and through better operational execution.

PM

Debbie Hewitt

11:10 am
BE

Dig into it and they're claiming problems are self inflicted, largely.

PM

BE

Whilst competition has been growing in the market, the review indicates that this has not been the major factor behind the brand's weak performance.

We have identified three main internal drivers of our underperformance:

11:10 am
BE

· We have lost value-conscious customers, a result of significant price increases and the removal of popular value offers. Above market increases in food and beverage pricing in 2013 and 2014 were compounded in 2015 by a reduction in value offers and the removal of a fixed price menu, actions which significantly reduced covers.

· In 2015, we began to introduce more "authentic" menus without sufficient testing of the concept. This led to the removal of many popular dishes from the menus and led to a further decline in covers.

· The absence of leadership for this key brand in the past two years resulted in weaker operating discipline and therefore an inconsistent and unsatisfactory service experience for many of our customers.

Reassuringly, the research confirms that the Frankie & Benny's brand and concept remain well loved by our customers. We have, however, over-priced the offer, removed some of their favourite dishes from the menu and lost focus on operational execution.

The review has helped us to achieve a much better understanding of our target customer: families who are "out and about", who are celebrating a specific family occasion or simply having a treat. Although it is clear that we also have wider appeal, the target market of families is very distinct and is the primary focus of our efforts as we rejuvenate the brand.

We are now clear about where we want to focus, who we want to measure ourselves against and how we will deliver. We have a detailed action plan, with many actions already underway.

· We have taken decisive action on those sites that don't meet the Frankie & Benny's positioning or returns criteria, with a number now set for closure, as set out earlier in this statement.

· We will look at the pricing architecture of the menu, re-invigorate the value offer and seek to understand how we can use our supply chain relationships to price engineer more effectively. We have already launched a series of pricing tests and menu trials, supported by local marketing initiatives in order to re-price for growth.

· We have appointed a new leader for the Frankie & Benny's brand, who started in June, and we are investing in our systems to improve the consistency of our operational execution.

Although we have slowed down the current restaurant roll out programme, the review indicates that once we have resolved these internal issues, there will be scope for further roll out of the Frankie & Benny's estate. This will be done in conjunction with a more disciplined framework for assessing each investment case.

BE

BE

But enough of actually looking at the business. Let's look at the numbers.

11:17 am
BE

Via Cazenove, which provides as comprehensive a wrap as anyone.

BE

We retain our Neutral rating following the release of Restaurant Group’s
interim results this morning, which are ahead of our previously reduced
expectations. LFLs of -3.9% for H1 are better than we expected, and the
decline rate has slowed more recently; this, with an extra week in FY16, leads
us to increase PBT by 3%. The main findings from the operating review to
date are that management believes a large proportion of the problems that
have led to the LFL declines are self-inflicted and is taking action to remedy
these problems. This includes increasing focus on restoring the value
proposition to try to win back lost customers. During this time, the group will
slow its roll out and today announced the closure of 33 sites where it does not
think enough improvement can be made. However, the dividend has been held
flat at 6.8p, and valuations remain relatively undemanding with the group
trading on FY16E/17E PERs of 13.8x/ 13.7x.

BE

H1 results. The results compare favorably to our forecasts. H1 LFLs of -
3.9% are ahead of our forecast of -5.0%, and the decline rate has slowed
more recently, following challenging trading during weeks 17-27. This was
due to a disappointing performance in Leisure being offset by a better
performance from the Pubs and Concessions. PBT of £36.6m is ahead of
our estimate of £30.6m, as is EPS of 14.3p vs. our estimate of 11.9p. The
dividend was held flat vs. our estimate of a cut to 5.6p.

11:17 am
BE

The review. To date, the review of the operating strategy has found that
TRG’s Leisure brands remain relevant, but that the performance has been
affected by factors such as insufficient focus on value, unsuccessful menu
development and poor operational execution. Guidance for FY16 PBT of
£74-80m is unchanged. Looking ahead, the group has identified risks of
rising input costs and will work hard to try to mitigate

BE

The plan. At Frankie and Benny’s, the largest brand, management intends to
refine the offer with a greater focus on families, trial new value offers and
add back popular dishes to the menu which were previously removed. The
group has also identified 33 underperforming sites for closure as
management do not believe these are capable of generating adequate returns,
and are writing down the asset value of a further 29 sites. Related to these,
the group will take a £59.1m pre-tax exceptional charge in H1, of which
£40.3m relates to impairments and £16.9m to onerous lease provisions. The
group also plans to slow the rollout, opening 24-28 sites this year, with
seven completed in H1.

BE

Changes to earnings estimates. Mostly due to an extra week in FY16, we
increase estimates by +3%, taking us to PBT of £77m. Our FY17E estimate of
£77m is unchanged. Our revenue estimates decrease as a result of closures and
a slower opening program. We assume the group maintains the dividend at
FY15 levels, which is an upgrade to our existing forecast, and adjust our
cashflow projects for lower capex, but also for exceptional costs associated
with the operating strategy. This causes our FY16 net debt forecast to rise from
£39m to £58m, representing ND/EBITDA of 0.4x. On LFLs, we estimate -
5.0% for FY16 and flat for FY17.

11:18 am
BE

Valuation. On our estimates, the stock trades on FY16E/17E PERs of
13.8x/13.7x, EV/EBITDA of 7.2x/7.0x and dividend yields of 3.6%/3.6%. Our
June 2017 price target increases due to decreasing the discount at which we
value the group to the peer group, and this results in an increase in the price
target from 330p to 390p.

11:25 am
BE

Have some Barclays .....

BE

Self-inflicted brand issues seen as the key problem, rather than oversupply, but cost of achieving volume turnaround remains unclear

· The findings of the strategy review suggest that although competition has had an effect on trading, the bigger issue has been poor value / menu development at Frankie & Benny’s.

· We view this as a better starting point than oversupply being the key issue, as it suggests that weakness in trading has been self-inflicted rather than largely due to the external backdrop of high competition.

· The action being taken will focus on “pricing, proposition and customer service”. The company’s findings, conducted alongside consultants OC&C, are that “Above market increases in food and beverage pricing in 2013 and 2014 were compounded in 2015 by a reduction in value offers and the removal of a fixed price menu, actions which significantly reduced covers”.

· We believe that the key unknown is the cost to achieve lower pricing and an enhanced customer proposition.

· Our analysis indicates that a 100bps decline for the Frankie & Benny’s estate (c50% of the total group) would drive a 4.9% hit to group EPS. A significant volume response (shown in case 5, below) would be required to offset this, before we consider any further maintenance capex required.

BE

Credible turnaround set out, now for the execution. Retain EW.

We view this as a credible turnaround strategy. Chairman Debbie Hewitt and new CFO Barry Nightingale have wasted no time in taking action, even before the arrival of the CEO. The company has set out a plan to cut poorly performing sites, and has a clear plan relating to the rest of the estate, which could stimulate a recovery. That all said, our analysis above sets out that substantial volume gains will be required to offset headwinds from lower prices and an improved customer proposition. Additional maintenance capex may be required to achieve this, and competition remains significant.

With the shares now trading on an FY16E PE of 15x, EV/EBITDA of 7.5x, and a FCF yield of 8%, we do not see these as trough multiples. Our EW rating balances the upside potential from turnaround against a strong recovery in the valuation ahead of the evidence of a successful turnaround with associated cost risks.

11:27 am
undefined

So, what else do we have to fill the time pre Yellen?

PM

Well, i should throw up a bit of stuff on Yellen herself

PM

PM

From Citi

11:28 am
PM

They've done a survey

PM

which covers most of the bases

PM

85% of respondents read Yellen as leaning to one 2016 hike;

· Hiking risk overwhelmingly in December even if September hiking risk modestly underpriced

· About 2/3rds expect an indication of a December hike in the speech, with many more seeing it in abroad dovish context, rather than hawkish

· … but respondents see market as expecting just over 50% probability that 2016 hike is indicated in speech

· Almost 50% see higher EM as the outcome, but much more split on G10 outcomes

11:29 am
PM

f she delivers a dovish long term message but signals one 2016 hike investors expect to:

o Buy EM

o Buy S&P

o Buy10s

o Sell 2s

o A couple of respondents would buy EM debt or other parts of the US yield curve

PM

Less than 10% think Yellen will endorse a higher inflation/nominal GDP/price level target, but 25% think she will refer to inflation asymmetry. Remaining 2/3rd expect her to stick to 2%

· 29% think they will change their targets in the next two years (but not necessarily signaled at JH); 50% think the targets will change only if there is a recession

We had almost 350 responses – about 40% came from the leveraged community, 21% real money, 23% Citi colleagues, 5% corporate and a smattering of central bankers and others.

PM

And welcome to this edition of Waiting around for Yellen

11:30 am
PM

The expectation of short-term dovish and long term hawkish indciate that investors are looking to buy on dips if she makes a December hike even more live (although 65% chance of hike priced for December looks pretty live to me already). The risk to this approach is if liquidity is poor and the short term selling leads to a bigger market sell-off, or if buying sentiment becomes so strong that prices move faster than investors are able to hit the buy button.

There is a very strong consensus (85%) that Yellen (85%) expects to do one hike this year, and most expect then next Fed move to be a hike (77%). About 2/3rds are looking for an explicit hiking signal at JH. I see these odds as too high – they may hike if everything goes perfectly Yellen. But if you take out September, the benefit from having an explicit lean seems low.

PM

My expectation is that she signals that she is open to hiking but needs to see more data and wants to see the economy running hot. I also think she feels that strong demand growth will improve productivity (more investment) and participation (higher wages induce labor supply), so she will accept a hike if things are going really well and the hike is innocuous, but not if she still feels they are failing on demand side. This will come across as dovish in my view.

PM

Done

BE

Sector first. Balance sheets okay, is the gist.

11:37 am
BE

Our analysis of credit lines indicates most companies have sufficient liquidity:
Given negative sentiment on Oil Services and a focus on balance sheets, we
undertake a deep dive through all the credit lines for the companies under our
coverage, using our existing base case forecasts. We conclude that most
companies have sufficient liquidity until at least 2020, if we assume that
companies can refinance existing bonds, which we consider the base case in the
current credit environment. Refinancing risk largely relates to 2018 and 2019,
rather than the near term. Our analysis implies that CGG and PGS may require
additional capital, in line with our existing forecasts . However, we recognise that
the wide margin of error in forecasting cash flows for seismic companies means
this might be overly conservative.

BE

Best positioned: We analyse leverage ratios using an approach similar to that of
credit rating agencies, comparing sources of liquidity to uses of liquidity in the
next 12 months. Credit rating agencies suggest that 1.2x is an effective minimum.
The liquidity ratio we calculate is more conservative, yet most of our companies
are still comfortably above this level. We see Aker Solutions, Wood Group,
Subsea 7 and Saipem as best positioned in terms of liquidity. We are Overweight
Aker Solutions, Subsea 7 and Wood Group, all with a liquidity ratio above 5x for
2017 and 4x for 2018. Technip is also in a strong position, in our view.

BE

Seismic most at risk: PGS and CGG are among the most operationally and
financially geared companies in our space, and our forecasts continue to imply
that they could require additional capital. We see a risk that CGG may need
~$296m of new capital by mid-2017 and PGS may require ~$125m by end-2017.
Both companies have refinancing due in 2018, and we see some risk around
covenants, although these have been revised upwards in the past.

11:38 am
BE

... and on Amec specifically .....

Amec Foster Wheeler PLC (AMFW:LSE): Last: 578.00, up 41 (+7.64%), High: 578.50, Low: 544.00, Volume: 941.00k
BE

Balance sheet de-gearing: The key debate for the stock in our view is whether
further cost savings, which we expect the new CEO to announce on Nov 15th, can
outweigh the earnings dilution from the planned £500m disposal of assets, itself
an important factor in the investment case to reduce balance sheet gearing to
more sustainable levels. We estimate these assets have an associated EBITA of
~£80m, some 27% of our previous 2017 forecast. We are concerned this is higher
than the market expects and would imply AMEC trades on a higher 2018 P/E
multiple than consensus estimates suggest.

11:39 am
BE

Restructuring story: We expect the new CEO to focus on monetising the
significant cost savings potential we see, in addition to the existing cost savings
plan. We forecast £100m of further annualised savings starting from 1H17 with
full impact in 2019. This additional target represents just 2% of cash costs and
we provide a scenario analysis (page 7) of what different ranges of cost savings
would mean for valuation and balance sheet gearing. While we lower 2017e EPS
by 14% to capture the dilution from disposals before cost savings are realised, we
increase 2018e EPS by 9% and 2019/20e EPS by ~15% as cost savings kick in.

BE

Attractive valuation: Consensus' P/E multiples of 10.3x in 2017 and 9.3x in 2018
look undemanding following 25% underperformance vs the sector in the past 12
months, and compare favourably to the historical FY1 average of 12.8x given
below-normalised earnings at this point in the cycle. We recognise that the P/E
multiple would look more demanding following the removal of ~£80m of EBITA
due to asset disposals. However, we expect this to be more than offset by cost
savings and multiples to remain undemanding. We expect the stock to re-rate as
the cost savings story develops and the cycle continues to improve.

BE

Where we could be wrong: Balance sheet concerns may return if the planned
£500m of asset disposals do not go ahead. A further risk is that the cost savings
potential is less than we assume and the market begins to price this in

11:45 am
BE

In summary, the policy sets out the following
1) the process by which Restricted Shareholders can seek consent from the Board of Directors for the creation of a Pledge in respect of any of their Restricted Shares

2) the information and confirmations which a Restricted Shareholder will be required to provide in order to obtain a Pledge Consent; and

3) the basis on which the Board of Directors will consider and respond to a Pledge Consent Request.

BE

Decision authority:
· The Board of Directors may confer its powers under this Pledging Policy to the Finance Committee or another Board committee

Financing arrangement:
· Within the pledging policy, references to financing arrangements mean any bona fide loan, credit facility, note, surety bonds (or other arrangements to secure a stay of execution on or the satisfaction of a judgment or order), letter of credit or any similar extension of credit to a Restricted Shareholder or any hedging, derivative, or other financing transaction

· Restricted Shareholder desiring to Pledge their Restricted Shares or any interests therein shall provide the Company for consideration by the Board of Directors with a written request in the form published on the Company’s website from time to time (a Pledge Consent Request)

Must include (amongst other information, see document for full list):
· a summary of the relevant Financing Arrangements in connection with which the Pledge is to be entered into (the Relevant Financing Arrangements), including: the material terms of the proposed Pledge and Relevant Financing Arrangements (to include, without limitation, the terms on which the Pledge may be enforced);

The pledge must include the following representations and warranties:
· the proposed Pledge and Relevant Financing Arrangements are being entered into for bona fide commercial reasons and not for the purpose (whether sole or collateral) of avoiding the restrictions on transfer of the Restricted Shares or to bring about an early conversion of Restricted Shares into Ordinary Shares, each as set out in the Articles of Association

· Restricted Shareholder (and, if different, the beneficial owner of the Restricted Shares to which the proposed Pledge relates) does not, acting reasonably, expect the proposed Pledge to be enforced prior to 10 October 2021;

· the relevant Restricted Shareholder (and, if different, the beneficial owner of the Restricted Shares to which the proposed Pledge relates) does not, acting reasonably, expect the Pledgee under the proposed Pledge to be or become entitled to exercise any right to enforce the Pledge prior to 10 October 2021

Any Pledge Consent Request shall be provided to the Company:
(a) within the period of 1 month following 10 October 2016; or
(b) during January, May or September of each calendar year, or such other period as the Company may from time to time specify by reasonable written notice.
2.3 A Restricted Shareholder (and its affiliates) shall not submit more than 2 Pledge Consent Requests to the Company in aggregate in any 12 month period.

Timing with respect to decision
The Board of Directors shall communicate in writing to the relevant Restricted Shareholder its decision (each, a Pledge Consent Decision) as to whether or not to provide a Pledge Consent within two months of receiving the Pledge Consent Request

Material provisions on the Scheme document dealing with the PSAs
To save reading the whole document, set out below are the relevant sections from the main body of the scheme document that deals with the PSA. Again there does not appear to be any material changes other than to pad out the wording around what is pledging or raising financing on Restricted Shares

BE

Contact Olivetree for the full analysis.

11:47 am
BAE Systems PLC (BA.:LSE): Last: 539.68, up 11.18 (+2.12%), High: 541.00, Low: 533.00, Volume: 3.00m
BE

Which gets a push from Berenberg.

BE

● We upgrade our rating to a Buy and raise our price target to 580p. We
anticipate a material order book uplift, an improving cash profile in 2017
(with potential upside to guidance), and a secure progressive dividend across
our forecast.

11:49 am
BE

580p target hardly looks blistering ....

BE

● Substantial order book uplift expected in the next six months: We
anticipate a material order intake, which could generate a 10-20% uplift to
the £36.6bn order book (as at H1 FY 2016). Following the UK parliamentary
vote in favour of funding the Successor programme, we anticipate an award
in excess of £1bn (possibly as early as September) to reflect the
commencement of the production phase for one year. We also anticipate the
renewal of a five-year Saudi support contract (we estimate the total value at
c£7bn, although caution that the award may be announced in incremental
stages rather than at the headline value), and an original equipment order for
an additional 48 Typhoon aircraft (which we value at c£4bn). We also flag the
Indian M777 opportunity (currently outside of the plan) which we value at
$750m (c£500m-550m).

BE

● Improving cash flows in 2017 with potential upside: The improvement in
cash flow is driven by the completion of provision utilisation, major usage of
advances ending (such as the Omani Typhoon prepayment), and the
completion of the San Diego ship repair facility. We note that FY 2016/17E
cash guidance excludes any assumption of a prepayment for the anticipated
Saudi Typhoon deal. On our workings, it is feasible that BAE may receive a
15% advance which would imply an inflow of c£400m-500m in 2017, thereby
reducing our net debt estimate to £1.1bn, and gearing to 0.5x (excluding
pensions).

11:49 am
BE

● Pension cash contribution fears are overdone: Despite falling discount rates
and the likelihood of a material deficit increase (from £2.6bn) at the next
triennial valuation in April 2017, we believe that any substantial rise in cash
contributions from the current £300m run rate is likely to be “smoothed” by
an extension to the recovery plan (from nine years in FY 2017 to at least 12
years). In our view, although BAE’s pension position and cash contributions
are negative drivers for sentiment, we remind investors that changes will not
affect cash flows until 2018, and we do not expect a material impact on
current estimates.

● Fundamentals: We raise our FY 2016/17/18 EPS by 5%/8%/8% respectively
to reflect the H1 FY 2016 results, FX profit tailwinds from post-Brexit sterling
weakness, and a healthy US market where the book-to-bill ratio is
strengthening.
● Valuation: Despite BAE’s re-rating over the past year, the stock currently
trades on an FY 2017 P/E multiple of 12.5x and an EV/EBIT multiple of 11.7x,
which is at a 30%/10% discount to US pure-play defence peers respectively.
Our revised target price places the stock in line on an EV/EBIT basis.

PM

Fourth UBS Evidence Lab UK consumer survey
Our survey asks 2000 UK consumers about their shopping preferences with a focus on clothing, DIY and discount retailing. Consumer expectations for discretionary income and personal financial situation are weaker than one year ago with expectations to spend strongest in discount retail and grocery, DIY saw a healthy yoy increase with clothing and homewares broadly flat yoy. UK consumers are viewing ease of shopping online/mobile and promotions as being increasingly important. The stock callouts from the survey are positive for Inditex, Primark, ASOS and B&M whilst more mixed for M&S, Kingfisher and Debenhams.

PM

Our UBS Evidence Lab survey shows no slowdown in Amazon growth
The survey provides some further insight into Amazon Prime in the UK with 21% of survey respondents having Prime membership which would equate to c.5.5m households in the UK. Twice as many Prime members expect to increase net spending on clothing in the next 12m on Amazon compared to the national average which may put further pressure on incumbent retailers. In clothing more consumers have bought clothing at Amazon than at M&S in the last 12 months – an interesting fact or potential tipping point. In DIY Amazon is the third most common retailer for DIY shopping and the second fastest growing albeit we think this reflects a relatively low spend per customer given the overall online penetration in the DIY category.

All quiet on the West End front
UK non-food retailers are almost unanimous in reporting no material impact on trading thus far post the referendum with a two-week lull and then a return to normality as the political situation stabilised. The only direct impact so far is the prospect of slightly lower mortgage rates. However, there may have been some benefit from warm weather in July, as opposed to the June washout, which helped clearance in apparel. The sector has now recovered c.10% from its immediate mauling following the vote.

The pain trades are:
· an indication of a September hike – she may try and spin as dovish long-term but it remains so unexpected that it will be hard for her to be convincing and market will sell off. Pain could be mitigated if she indicated only one hike in 2016.
